Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Unique Structural Proteins and Cross-linking Reactions that Control Physical Properties of Insect Exoskeletons
Award.AbstractNarration: The exoskeleton of insects functions as both skin and supporting skeleton. It is formed from a material called cuticle, composed of proteins and a carbohydrate (chitin), and simple organic compounds known as catechols. Despite this limited compositional palette, cuticle has remarkably diverse properties, ranging from soft and flexible to hard and rigid. It is quite strong, but it is lightweight compared with bone of vertebrate animals, because cuticle lacks mineral components. The mechanical properties of insect exoskeleton have certainly contributed to the overwhelming success of insects in adapting to nearly every habitat and in their development of the ability to fly. This proposal describes experiments to investigate the biochemical compounds and chemical reactions that form insect cuticle and to understand how these result in cuticular regions with differing mechanical properties. This interdisciplinary project, involving biochemists and engineers, makes use of the red flour beetle, Tribolium castaneum, as a model organism to investigate the relationships of cuticle protein properties and chemistry with the development of rigid cuticle. The proposed approaches combine molecular and mechanical analysis to yield advances in fundamental understanding of cuticle biochemistry and development of potentially useful new materials based on cuticle chemistry. Broader impacts resulting from the research will include education and training for undergraduate and graduate students. Specific efforts at broadening opportunities for participation in science will include research experiences by diverse undergraduate students and outreach to middle school and high school students. Advances in understanding of this critical physiological system in insects will lead to a deeper knowledge of insect biology will aid in producing new types of cross-linked biopolymers based on the chemistry of cuticle. This new class of 'bioinspired' materials has potential technological applications in medicine, pharmacy and agriculture.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Insect cuticle, the primary component of the exoskeleton, is one of the most widespread materials in nature. It is comprised of a relatively small set of organic molecular components: the polysaccharides chitin and chitosan, a number of different proteins and small reactive molecules known as catechols.  Despite the compositional similarity of different cuticles, their physical properties range from soft, flexible materials as found in leg and wing joints to stiff, rigid materials like the wing covers of beetles (known as elytra). 

The exceptional properties of insect cuticle are hypothesized to arise from a combination of covalent and non-covalent interactions among proteins, catechols, chitosan and chitin nanofibers, including protein-catechol crosslinking, generation of catechol-derived microparticles and protein-metal ion interactions. Using a combination of biophysical techniques, we examined the interactions between novel structural proteins we have identified in the red flour beetleTribolium castaneumand their interactions with chitin, chitosan and metal ions. We used both molecular biological techniques and mechanical test methods on the whole elytra from the beetle models Tribolium castaneumandTenebrio molitor, to advance understanding of composition-structure-property relationships in cuticle. 

Two abundant cuticle proteins in the elytra of T. castaneumthat our collaborators at Kansas State University named CPR27 and CP30 were the foci of this study. CPR27 has a sequence of amino acids called "RR2" hypothesized to bind chitin, while the role of non-RR protein CP30 was unknown. Our major result was to obtain direct evidence of selective chitin binding of RR2 by using an active microrheology technique, coupled with fluorescence and bright-field microscopy. While our results from active microrheology showed that addition of CPR27 to aqueous chitosan solutions caused a 2-fold decrease in viscosity, simultaneous visualization of the solution microstructure shows the formation of micron-sized particles. Together these results indicated that CPR27 complexed with chitosan as hypothesized. Fluorescence microscopy also showed that the protein CPR27 serves as a nucleation agent to induce the complexation of the polyelectrolyte. In contrast, CP30, which does not contain the chitin-binding sequence, displayed no evidence of complexation.  

The role of quinone-crosslinking of both proteins with the catechol N-β-alanyldopamine (similar to that observed in mussel adhesion)was also examined using this combination of passive microrheology and microparticle analysis. Microparticle formation was observed in solutions containing protein, catechol and the oxidative enzyme laccase. Interestingly there were small variations in the average size of the particles with larger particles forming when protein CPR27 interacted with the enzyme laccase. A corresponding increase in viscosity was also observed. 

Using a technique known as RNA-interference in beetle pupae, the amount of CP30 and CPR27 could be selectively reduced in the adult beetle elytra. With CPR27 reduction, the stiffness of the elytra dropped and the viscoelasticity dropped as a result, but with CP30 reduction, while there was little impact on the stiffness, the viscoelasticity increased.  Synthetically prepared chitin films have a stiffness comparable to elytra, but have almost no viscoelasticity.  Thus this work confirms the different roles of CPR27 and CP30 in determining the stiffness and viscoelasticity of the cuticle, and suggests that chitin interactions dominate stiffness but proteins alter viscoelasticity. Understanding the interactions involving these cuticle proteins suggest new motifs that could be used in the design of new composite materials.  The rational design of recombinant proteins following these principles, with specific covalent and non-covalent interactions with polysaccharides or ions, inspired by insect cuticle, may lead to biomaterials with enhanced mechanical properties.

The results of this work have been broadly disseminated. Three refereed journal publications and eight conference presentations (USA, Japan and Sweden) have resulted to date (plus additional papers from collaborators on this grant at Kansas State University). Four of the conference presentations were invited, with three at materials science conferences, and one at an entomology conference.  Additionally, PI Gehrke was interviewed on public radio about the project. Hence a very broad audience of PhD-level researchers in materials science and entomology plus the general public have learned how molecular design of insect cuticle leads to the observed properties.  Additionally, the microrheological techniques developed in the course of this project by co-PI Dhar has led to the development of techniques and software that can be used by others in areas unrelated to insect cuticle, such as the stabilization of therapeutic protein formulations.

 The project has also advanced the education of ten graduate and undergraduate students. One student to date has earned her Ph.D. with support from this grant, with two other Ph.D. students and an M.S. student nearing completion of their dissertations on the mechanics of insect cuticle. In addition to these students who focused on cuticle for their dissertations, four other PhD students and three undergraduate students contributed to aspects of this project. Three faculty other than the PIs and coPIs also contributed to the advances made in this work, hence familiarizing them with the principles of cuticle design.
